articles.headline: Winfrey’s Channel Is Set to Break Through
articles.snippet: The Oprah Winfrey Network is benefiting from Lance Armstrong’s interview and a deal to expand revenue.
articles.abstract: The Oprah Winfrey Network is benefiting from Lance Armstrong’s interview and a deal to expand revenue.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last Tuesday afternoon, Oprah Winfrey called the co-presidents of her cable channel OWN with some jump-on-the-couch-with-joy news. “Lance wants to talk,” she said, referring to Lance Armstrong, whom she had been courting for a confessional interview about his long-denied use of performance-enhancing drugs.

articles.headline: Pauline Phillips, Flinty Adviser to Millions as Dear Abby, Dies at 94
articles.snippet: With her comic, tart-tongued yet fundamentally sympathetic voice, Mrs. Phillips helped wrestle the advice column from its weepy Victorian past into a hard-nosed 20th-century present.
articles.abstract: With her comic, tart-tongued yet fundamentally sympathetic voice, Mrs. Phillips helped wrestle the advice column from its weepy Victorian past into a hard-nosed 20th-century present.
articles.lead_paragraph: Dear Abby: My wife sleeps in the raw. Then she showers, brushes her teeth and fixes our breakfast — still in the buff. We’re newlyweds and there are just the two of us, so I suppose there’s really nothing wrong with it. What do you think? — Ed

articles.headline: Dell’s Ups and Downs With Options
articles.snippet: Dell has spent more on share repurchases than it earned throughout its life as a public company, and most of those repurchases were at prices well above current levels.
articles.abstract: Dell has spent more on share repurchases than it earned throughout its life as a public company, and most of those repurchases were at prices well above current levels.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was an amazing American success story, in which a college student in his dorm room created what became one of the largest computer companies in the world. In the 1990s, its share price tripled in each of three consecutive years. But after the bubble burst, it resorted to accounting fraud to persuade investors it was doing better than it really was.

articles.headline: As Shell’s Arctic Drilling Hopes Hit Snags, Its Rivals Watch
articles.snippet: Shell’s drilling program, the subject of two federal inquiries, has had problems environmentalists say highlight the dangers of prospecting for oil in the severe Arctic environment.
articles.abstract: Shell’s drilling program, the subject of two federal inquiries, has had problems environmentalists say highlight the dangers of prospecting for oil in the severe Arctic environment.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Royal Dutch Shell’s Arctic drilling program is now officially in jeopardy and its prospects will depend on the findings of two continuing federal inquiries. One review is on the grounding of the Kulluk drill ship on New Year’s Eve after it was set adrift for five days in stormy weather, and the other is on the safety management of the entire Shell program.
articles.byline: By Clifford Krauss and John M. Broder

articles.headline: Mortgage Crisis Lingers On at Citigroup and Bank of America
articles.snippet: Most banks have recovered from the recent financial collapse, but the two companies reported continuing effects on earnings.
articles.abstract: Most banks have recovered from the recent financial collapse, but the two companies reported continuing effects on earnings.
articles.lead_paragraph: More than four years after the financial crisis, many big banks have regained their footing. But Bank of America and Citigroup remain dogged by the past.
articles.byline: By Ben Protess and Jessica Silver-Greenberg

articles.headline: Michael Dell’s Empire in a Buyout Spotlight
articles.snippet: The computer mogul Michael Dell, in talks to acquire the company he started as a teenager, has built a reputation as a shrewd investor.
articles.abstract: The computer mogul Michael Dell, in talks to acquire the company he started as a teenager, has built a reputation as a shrewd investor.
articles.lead_paragraph: The computer empire of Michael S. Dell spreads across a campus of low-slung buildings in Round Rock, Tex.

articles.headline: Banker Behind Armstrong Says He Was Unaware of Doping
articles.snippet: Thomas Weisel, who bankrolled Lance Armstrong through seven Tour de France wins, said in his first public comment on the matter that he never personally saw an instance of doping on the team.
articles.abstract: Thomas Weisel, who bankrolled Lance Armstrong through seven Tour de France wins, said in his first public comment on the matter that he never personally saw an instance of doping on the team.
articles.lead_paragraph: The financier Thomas Weisel recently boxed up the bright-yellow cycling jerseys that lined an entire wall of his office, which overlooks San Francisco’s harbor. They were gifts from Lance Armstrong, a longtime friend whom Mr. Weisel had bankrolled through seven Tour de France wins.

articles.headline: Praised but Fire-Prone, Battery Fails Test in 787
articles.snippet: Lithium-ion batteries are popular because they are powerful and charge quickly, but Boeing has had serious problems with the technology on its new Dreamliner.
articles.abstract: Lithium-ion batteries are popular because they are powerful and charge quickly, but Boeing has had serious problems with the technology on its new Dreamliner.
articles.lead_paragraph: Powerful and lightweight, lithium-ion batteries are the perfect power source for modern gadgets. But ubiquitous as they are, their short history has also been fraught with problems — they have caught fire in cellphones, laptop computers and electric cars, and even destroyed a small Navy submarine.
articles.byline: By Jad Mouawad and Christopher Drew

articles.headline: Jihad ‘Prince,’ a Kidnapper, Is Tied to Raid
articles.snippet: The man thought to have masterminded the kidnapping at the Algerian natural gas field has a long history in smuggling, jihad and politics in the region.
articles.abstract: The man thought to have masterminded the kidnapping at the Algerian natural gas field has a long history in smuggling, jihad and politics in the region.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — His entourage calls him “the Prince,” and after the militant Islamist takeover of a town in northern Mali last year, he liked to go down to the river and watch the sunset, surrounded by armed bodyguards.
articles.byline: By Steven Erlanger and Adam Nossiter

articles.headline: Harsh Light Falls on Bolshoi After Acid Attack
articles.snippet: Moscow awoke to the horrifying news on Friday that a masked man had thrown acid on Sergei Filin, the artistic director of one of the city’s jewels, the Bolshoi Ballet.
articles.abstract: Moscow awoke to the horrifying news on Friday that a masked man had thrown acid on Sergei Filin, the artistic director of one of the city’s jewels, the Bolshoi Ballet.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — The stories about vengeance at the Bolshoi Ballet go back centuries: The rival who hid an alarm clock in the audience, timed to go off during Giselle’s mad scene, or who threw a dead cat onto the stage at curtain in lieu of flowers. There are whispers of needles inserted in costumes, to be discovered in midpirouette, or — the worst — broken glass nestled in the tip of a toeshoe.

articles.headline: Despite Improving Profits, Morgan Stanley’s Path Is Uncertain
articles.snippet: Morgan Stanley reported adjusted earnings of 45 cents a share on Friday, driven by gains in wealth management and investment banking.
articles.abstract: Morgan Stanley reported adjusted earnings of 45 cents a share on Friday, driven by gains in wealth management and investment banking.

articles.headline: Hiding, Praying, Tied to Bombs: Captives Detail Algerian Ordeal
articles.snippet: Hostages who escaped or were freed described gunshots ringing out during breakfast, followed by foreigners being separated from Algerians.
articles.abstract: Hostages who escaped or were freed described gunshots ringing out during breakfast, followed by foreigners being separated from Algerians.
articles.lead_paragraph: The gunmen, dressed in fatigues and wearing turbans, stormed in well before dawn aboard pickup trucks, announcing their arrival with a burst of gunfire.
articles.byline: By Lydia Polgreen and Scott Sayare

articles.headline: In Budget Talks, Getting to ‘Yes’
articles.snippet: Negotiating experts consider how President Obama and Republican leaders might achieve goals without subjecting the markets, the American people and the global economy to a game of chicken.
articles.abstract: Negotiating experts consider how President Obama and Republican leaders might achieve goals without subjecting the markets, the American people and the global economy to a game of chicken.

articles.headline: Days Before Housing Bust, Fed Doubted Need to Act
articles.snippet: The Federal Reserve has released the full record of its discussions in 2007, when the housing market, the financial system and the economy took a fateful turn.
articles.abstract: The Federal Reserve has released the full record of its discussions in 2007, when the housing market, the financial system and the economy took a fateful turn.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When Federal Reserve policy makers convened in August 2007, one of the nation’s largest subprime mortgage lenders had just filed for bankruptcy, and another was struggling to find the money it needed to survive.
